definitions.definition: To or in a previous condition or place.
examples: He gave back the money.
I left my mobile phone back at the hotel. I’ll have to go back and get it.

definitions.definition: In a direction opposite to that in which someone or something is facing or normally pointing.
examples: Someone pushed me in the chest and I fell back .
The grandfather clock toppled back and crashed to the ground.
Her arm was bent back at an odd angle.

definitions.definition: In a direction opposite to the usual or desired direction of movement or progress, physically or figuratively.
examples: Wind the film back a few frames.
Don’t forget to put the clocks back by one hour tonight!
This mishap has set the project back considerably.

definitions.definition: Towards, into or in the past.
examples: These records go back years.
He built a time machine and travelled back to 1800.
Think back to how you felt last year.
Everything was simpler back in the old days.

definitions.definition: Away from someone or something; at a distance.
examples: Keep back ! It could explode at any moment!

definitions.definition: Away from the front or from an edge.
examples: Sit all the way back in your chair.
Step back from the curb.

definitions.definition: So as to shrink, recede or move aside, or cause to do so.
examples: This tree is dying back .
Clear back all this vegetation.
Draw back the curtains and let in some light.
Fear held him back .

definitions.definition: In a reciprocal manner; in return .
examples: If you hurt me, I’ll hurt you back .
The light bounces back off the mirror.
We met many years back .
I last saw him a day or two back .

definitions.definition: To a later point in time. See also put back .
examples: The meeting has been moved back an hour. It was at 3 o’clock; now it's at 4 o’clock.

main_definition: ( not comparable ) To or in a previous condition or place.
secondary_definitions: In a direction opposite to that in which someone or something is facing or normally pointing.
In a direction opposite to the usual or desired direction of movement or progress, physically or figuratively.
Towards, into or in the past.
Away from someone or something; at a distance.
Away from the front or from an edge.
So as to shrink, recede or move aside, or cause to do so.
( not comparable ) In a reciprocal manner; in return .
To a later point in time. See also put back .
